dataset.title: Development Tendencies of Forest Management Research in Taiwan as Exemplified by TFRI's Publications in the Last 50 years

associatedParty.positionName: Head of Division of Forest Management

abstract.para: The study aims at analyzing the relationships between the research tendency and human resources in terms of forest management subject of Taiwan Forestry Research Institute (TFRI) from 1947 to 2000 by means of adopting bibliometrics and sociometrics. There were 165 papers regarding forest management completed within the period, equivalently 15% of the amount of TFRI’s total papers published. Quantitatively, these researches were mostly focused on traditional forest management, forest economics and forest planning, but less concentrated on forest policy and forest recreation. Generally speaking, the papers still stressed on the core concepts of traditional forest management such as timber production or plantation management; however, new issues from the viewpoints of ecology and society emerged in the last decade. Since TFRI is suffered from the shortage of manpower, the minority of researchers who have high academic productivity usually dominate its performance in forest management subject. The study also indicates that the faster the turnover of researchers, the more the innovation and diffusion of research concepts.

section.title: sociometrics
section.para: Sociometrics is described as a science that involves the study and measurement of relationships, social structures, and mental health. It involves the measurement of groups and the behavior and status of individuals within such groups.Sociometrics involves taking a different approach to understanding group alliances. Unlike other sciences, it requires the exploration of social groups and organizations from the core of the structures. Sociometrics deals with revealing and analyzing the hidden beliefs, alliances, and hidden agendas of group structures. It also involves the analysis of group substructure. Sociometrics works under the premise that each of these elements, from alliances to subgroups, combine to give form to groups and organizations.
